Definitely not for everyone, but an amazing treat for hardcore JRPG fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045298305', 'num_games_owned': 4521, 'num_reviews': 233, 'playtime_forever': 1516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1705999475}
review:
I dunno why this has mixed reviews its a SaGa game, they have wonky mechanics, perma death for your characters if you lose all your LP and wild wacky formations + skill combos.


It looks great, runs great on the deck.

Sounds fantastic.

It was also never released in America and now we have it. HOW GLORIOUS IS THAT.


30 fps cap does make me weep tho. Not enough to stop me from enjoying it tho!

author: {'steamid': '76561198054151008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1428, 'last_played': 1702674652}
review:
Half of the game is setting up your party's equipment, skills, and magic after a party wipe/generation skip.

The other half of the game is save scumming so you don't have to spend time setting up your party's equipment, skills, and magic.

A decently enjoyable SNES-era JRPG with some major balance issues. Lots of great ideas for a game, but haphazardly thrown together.

Save 40-60 hours of your life by consulting a guide. It would be best to read a guide in its entirety before starting the game at all. I burned out before finishing the game, as I didn't feel like spending numerous hours grinding magic levels.

Recommended on sale if you wondered what you were missing in 1993 outside of Japan.

[hr][/hr]

p.s., alright, Square, now we're ready for [i]Treasure of the Rudras[/i], [i]Bahamut Lagoon[/i], [i]Actraiser II[/i] (with city building but don't screw it up with tower defense), [i]Saga Frontier 2[/i], and [i]Xenogears[/i] remasters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254310912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3836, 'last_played': 1577167070}
review:
Shocked to see all the bad reviews for this game. 
It's great! Sure the UI that seems lifted straight from mobile isn't that aesthetically pleasing but every other aspect from the SFC original was ported fine to Steam. 
Essentially this game is a mix between your typical linear, narrative-centered JRPG gameplay and the more nonlinear, customizable WRPG gameplay, and it pulls that mixture off beautifully. It's a game that encourages experimentation and even restarting one's entire playthrough to apply what was learned from previous playthroughs. People who aren't aware of this upon booting the game may be confused and frustrated this isn't the kind of JRPG they were expecting, but for those ready for this game's offering it will be hard to put down. I also think the game's core narrative is pretty good and interesting despite being pretty sparse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019158253', 'num_games_owned': 952, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4087, 'last_played': 1695349649}
review:
A lot of the negative reviews are about how bad the port was a long time ago, that is not the case anymore.  There are some minor issues, but not enough to detract from the game, I'll go over them.  
1. No volume slider, I had to manually open my volume mixer in Windows to set the volume every time I started the game.  Easily the biggest problem I had.
2. No way to enter fullscreen, easily solvable by hitting alt+enter, pretty much a non-issue.  
3. To go back to the main menu (if you need to load a save), you can't use your mouse like the rest of the game, you have to select it with WASD then hit enter.  

Now that that's out of the way..  

This game is fantastic.  This is my first Romancing Saga game and I was blown away.  So much variety in the way you can do things from the classes, to the weapons/spells, to the formation and skills you can use for your party.  The game can be a LITTLE obtuse at times in telling you what to do.  I'd say like 80% of the time they give you a good enough direction in what to do, the other 20% I did not feel bad about glancing online.  And you should definitely glance at the Steam guides to figure out what armors actually do.

So the gameplay is great.  But what about the story?  Going in I was told that Romancing Saga isn't very story focused, and it's mostly about the gameplay.  I'm here to say I don't agree with that.  This game has some outstanding scenarios in it that are super creative.  The overarching story isn't bad, but it's the individual little stories in different towns that I love.  

If you don't mind doing a little learning on how this game works, you'll have an awesome time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011913641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3818, 'last_played': 1684428753}
review: Unique JRPG. Remaster of a SNES game that only came out in Japan. Combat is very "black box" and most of the fun of the game is learning to how to fight. No sitting back and holding X to grind in this game. Earthbound style encounters, where all enemies are visible in the overworld and can be dodged. Also uses a generational system. When you get a party wipe, you don't get a game over screen in Romancing Saga 2, you get to pick a new main character and keep going, building off of the stats and equipment you have acquired over your past characters. Not a wildly engrossing story, but uses more of an Elder Scrolls sort of hook, where the draw to keep playing is to become stronger to face harder challenges, and to explore the vast world. Recommend for any JRPG or Turn Based fan that is not turned off by a bit of the cryptic. If you hate researching and theorycrafting about the games you're playing, avoid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083983697', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 3723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3723, 'last_played': 1689442922}
review:
It's really hard to describe how advanced and ahead of it's time Romancing SaGa 2 is compared to other jRPGs released around same timeframe.
While in most jRPGs you are simply an observer of unfolding story and there is little you can change about it except grind a few levels or equip certain gear to make fights easier or harder, RS2 gives massive amount of choice on how and when handle quests, quests that might change with passage of time, quests that might change on you completing or not completing certain previous quests, and an open world to explore and to tackle these quests and bosses in any order you please.
The game originality shines even today as most jRPG-like games both AAA and indie ones would rather imitate more safe examples like Dragon Quest, Final Fantasy or Chrono Trigger, since RS game were originally not released outside of Japan so there is probably no nostalgia bait factor associated with them, which is a real shame.
The porting job itself is ok, a lot of reviews mention crashes, which I haven't encountered, and the background graphics and UI are of ugly mobile-port quality that clash with pixel character sprites, giving this game rather jarring artstyle, but you can get used to it.
And it's worth trying to get used to it since the base game is just great. First few runs of it when you constantly discover some new route, some new quest, some new thing about a boss, are just magical. It's one of those games that I wish I could forget all about it so I can experience discovering it and playing it for the first time all over again.

author: {'steamid': '76561199144029402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1041, 'last_played': 1688315894}
review:
ComprÃ© hace poco este juego, pero ya conocÃ­a parte de su historia y concepto hace tiempo. Romancing Saga 2 es un juego que puede resultar un poco mÃ¡s complejo que otros JRPG dada la dificultad que tienen los enemigos y la variada cantidad de cosas que puedes hacer dentro de Ã©l.

Recomiendo jugarlo, es una experiencia bastante interesante y con diferentes posibilidades en la historia al ser un mundo abierto, aunque probablemente necesites ayuda para entender las diferentes mecÃ¡nicas del juego que no se explican dentro de este.

Como punto en contra, el juego tiene solo dos opciones de idiomas y eso perjudica la experiencia a otros jugadores que pueden no tener mayor conocimiento de estos. TambiÃ©n la falta de un menÃº que permita modificar cosas bÃ¡sicas como el tamaÃ±o de la ventana (y no usar combinaciones de teclas), sonidos, etc hacen que se sienta mÃ¡s tosco.

Espero que sea de ayuda estos comentarios, saludos y disfruten su aventura en el reino de Avalon :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198031422744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2630, 'last_played': 1619228120}
review: Romancing Saga 2 is a game designed by Akitoshi Kawazu. Like with all other SaGa games that he designs and produces, it is ideal to approach this kind of game NOT with a typical console JRPG mindset that one would expect to have when playing a game of this genre, but with instead a more TTRPG/CRPG mindset. The real drive of of the SaGa franchise is to explore it's vast, detailed world, and to let the story or "saga" build from there. It does give you a unique premise to start off with: you are an imperial lineage of emperors/empresses battling with the fabled Seven Heroes of yore who have returned to the world during a period of great strife NOT to save said world, but to conquer/destroy it. An intriguing hook for sure, but like I said earlier, the narrative is there to spur you to go out into the world on your own. The narrative doesn't drag you along linearly in a set manner; You have to explore the world in order grow the story along with your party of characters. And the world is detailed and full of all kinds of life to encourage extensive exploration, it has over a dozen of recruitable playable characters/classes, dungeons to navigate, and secret treasures to unearth. Gameplay wise, It is a turn based JRPG, with no random encounters, which is nice. What makes this different from say Dragon Quest of Final Fantasy is that it is skill-based progression, not pure level progression. Basically, the more you do a certain action, that stronger that that action gets (i.e. uses swords frequently=sword level raises up=more special sword skills/"techs" get unlocked). All of these features that Kawazu and team have brought have helped make this game and many others in the SaGa franchise feel ahead of their time. Think of it as pre-"Elder Scrolls" with turn-based menu combat. It is an acquired taste, but if you acquire it like I've had, you might find yourself savoring it more and more. It can feel a little grindy if you're not too familiar with its mechanics, especially at first; But if you let it get under your skin for even just a little bit, you'd might be surprised at how compelling it actually is. Also, I find this to be one of Square-Enix's best remasters of a classic JRPG in years. Compared to some of their other mobile and pc ports (Particularly FF PRE-pixel remastered) it's visuals alone stand above its competitors. Keeping the 16-bit characters sprites BUT having the backgrounds be HD is a lot more pleasing to the eye than just trying to HD everything with mixed results. It does justice to Tomomi Kobayashi's vibrant artwork, which really gives it and the franchise as a whole its own unique identity. Also, just having Idle animations for bosses and supre-strong enemy monsters is a nice visual cue to the player about how strong their opponent is in comparison to them. Plus, it retains Kenji ito's original soundtrack as it was composed back in 1993 instead of just giving an orchestral upgrade. It really pairs well with the updated, yet traditional visuals to give you sense of how immersive Japanese players felt when they first played this game nearly 30 years ago. All in all, a compelling game in a compelling franchise if you give yourself the chance grok on its level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198380736351', 'num_games_owned': 1877, 'num_reviews': 553, 'playtime_forever': 1776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1776, 'last_played': 1658239308}
review:
A really good JRPG
Its quite obtuse and requires a lot of time to properly learn the systems
The story is okay nothing special but the journey is what matters in this game
If needed use the new game+ helps a lot
It has a lot of missable content so does have a lot of replayability as well
Overall if you like opended games and/or Jrpgs you'll probably like this

review:
An obtuse game with rules that are vague and hard to understand, systems designed to annoy and punish you for not playing correctly, definitely one of the most difficult turn based games i have played, recommended for people wanting a challenge and a decent narrative spanning over generations   

TLDR: truly the romancing saga 2 of video games

author: {'steamid': '76561198062686283', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3972, 'last_played': 1652263838}
review:
Highly recommended for jrpg fans that grew bored of cookie cutter stories, gameplay systems and the usual braindead battles.

If you haven't played another Saga game it's recommended to read a bit about how skill sparking and class types and affinities affect them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100609883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4040, 'last_played': 1687475671}
review:
[b]FULL DISCLOSURE[/b]: I love SaGa games, flaws and all, and this is maybe my 2nd or 3rd favorite entry. I include a few tips to hopefully improve your experience for those who have not played this or other SaGa games at the end.

Yes, there is some difficulty in this game that can be chalked up to SNES-era game design. In particular, there are a bunch of game systems that are not explained in-game, because all that stuff would have been explained in a physical manual that always came with these kinds of games. That said, if you enjoy a good challenge and can get used to all the usual SaGa quirks, this is an all-time great for a number of reasons:

--Kenji Ito's soundtrack shreds, as per usual
--Once you understand how SaGa games generally work (more on this below), the difficulty curve can be super enjoyable
--A number of innovative game systems that, frankly, I haven't seen too many other places since
--Although the writing is definitely a relic sometimes, I like the "develop your kingdom and fight the baddies over generations" schtick, culminating on one of my favorite sequences in a game during the final chapter
--The HD graphics are good, even if they look a bit odd combined with the still very pixelated heroes

For those who have not played much/any SaGa before, here are some things that might help you have a better time and not get wrecked by the difficulty curve:

--[b]First and foremost[/b]: Know that you out-power your opponents through finding gear much more than any stat gains/tech learning you will get naturally. Use that pseudo-open world to your advantage and explore for new gear in chests and shops! 

--Related: Try not to grind if possible! Grinding in SaGa means that you will start seeing tougher monsters earlier than you might like due to how encounters work, and there will be plenty of time to manage that progression later.

--Figure out who is best with what weapons (they often tell you this when you put them in your party), and try to shape your party to learn a wide variety of weapon skills (which are saved when moving to a new generation).

--Don't be afraid to start over if you think you botched things, especially if you think you botched Gerard's sequence. Once you understand how the empire-management and combat mechanics work, redoing the earlier parts will be much easier than you think!

--Finally, SaGa 2 specific tip for the final boss: If you do not choose the female emperor at the beginning (but really, even if you do), [b]do not save the female villain of the Seven Heroes for the end, and make sure to learn to evade her Temptation attack during the fight[/b]. The final boss will still be very difficult, but doing this will save you from having to deal with the cheapest OHKO it can potentially do from the start of the fight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011472145', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4771, 'last_played': 1663286504}
review: One of the most challenging and exciting JRPG experiences I've ever had. Interesting and addictive gameplay systems, brutal difficulty that will make you think and plan, and charming world to explore. Not heavy on story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054216330', 'num_games_owned': 437, 'num_reviews': 244, 'playtime_forever': 4083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4083, 'last_played': 1644101967}
review:
[h1]Vorwort[/h1]
Romancing Saga 2 ist optisch den Final Fantasy Spielen Ã¤hnlich, ist vom Anspruch her aber wesentlich hÃ¶her angesiedelt. Wer nicht eine gewisse Frusttoleranz besitzt und auch generell eher leichte Kost vorzieht, sollte besser einen Bogen darum machen.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b][u]KÃ¤mpfe auf Leben und Tod und ein KÃ¶nigliches Erbe[/u][/b]
Um ohne groÃŸ um den heiÃŸen Brei herum zu reden: Deine Charaktere kÃ¶nnen sterben. Also so richtig. 
Jeder Charakter, den man im Spiel in die Gruppe aufnehmen kann, hat eine gewisse Anzahl an [b]Lebenspunkten[/b]. Diese verringern sich um eins, wenn die Hitpoints des Charakters auf null fallen (was schneller passieren kann, als man glauben mag) und wenn er im bewusstlosen Zustand weiteren Schaden erleidet. Hat ein Charakter keine Lebenspunkte mehr, verschwindet er aus der Gruppe.
Das alles ist halb so wild, da man im Grunde endlosen Ersatz beschaffen kann und das Equipment des oder der verblichenen in der Imperialen Waffenkammer gehortet wird. Sollte der Imperator selbst mal den LÃ¶ffel abgeben, kann das sogar gut sein, da er seine FÃ¤higkeiten an ein Mitglied der Gruppe [b]vererbt[/b], welches dann selbst Imperator wird. 
Nach und nach wird der Imperator auf diese Weise immer stÃ¤rker.
Das gilt allerdings nur fÃ¼r seine [b]Meisterschaftsstufen[/b], die kurz gesagt mit bestimmen, wie effizient man Waffen und Magie nutzen kann. Attribute wie StÃ¤rke und Geschick werden nicht erhÃ¶ht.

[b][u]Die Macht der Formationen- Auf die Aufstellung kommt es an[/u][/b]
Im Kampf steht die Gruppe nicht nur einfach herum, sondern nimmt eine [b]Kampfformation[/b] ein, die bestimmten Gruppenmitgliedern diverse Vorteile wie eine hÃ¶here Angriffskraft oder eine verringerte Chance, selbst angegriffen zu werden verschafft. 
Formationen kÃ¶nnen im Spiel erlernt werden, wenn man als Imperator einer bestimmten Charakterklasse angehÃ¶rt und die Kaserne besucht.

[b][u]Die Macht des Lernens- Der Mathematikteil[/u][/b]
In Romancing Saga 2 gibt es keine Level-Ups, allerdings kÃ¶nnen Charaktere ihre Meisterschaftsstufen in verschiedenen Bereichen wie etwa dem Umgang mit bestimmten Waffen verbessern. AuÃŸerdem kÃ¶nnen die Hitpoints eines Charakters spontan steigen und FÃ¤higkeiten erlernt werden.
Es gibt drei Arten von FÃ¤higkeiten, die ein Charakter lernen kann. Magie, WaffenfÃ¤higkeiten und KonterfÃ¤higkeiten.
[b]WaffenfÃ¤higkeiten[/b] und KonterfÃ¤higkeiten werden im Kampf spontan gelernt, wenn man entweder den Gegner mit der Waffe attackiert oder selbst angegriffen wird. Hierbei sind WaffenfÃ¤higkeiten einfach neue Techniken, die nicht von jedem Charakter "geglimmert" werden kÃ¶nnen, was im Grunde bedeutet, dass der Charakter die FÃ¤higkeit im Kampf lernt. Welcher Charakter welche FÃ¤higkeiten glimmern kann wird im Spiel nicht erlÃ¤utert.
[b]KonterfÃ¤higkeiten[/b] erlernt ein Charakter eben so spontan, wenn er von Gegnern attackiert wird. Hierbei wird einfach jeder Effekt des Angriffs vermieden, was bei besonders starken Angriffen den Sieg bringen kann, aber eben nur diese eine Technik betrifft.
[b]Magie[/b] ist recht unkompliziert. Mit hÃ¶heren Meisterschaftsstufen in einer bestimmten Magieschule werden neue Zauber im Labor verfÃ¼gbar, die gelernt werden kÃ¶nnen. Allerdings schlieÃŸen bestimmte Magieschulen einander aus. Hat ein Charakter beispielsweise Feuermagie gelernt, kann er keine Wassermagie erlernen, es sei denn er verlernt die Feuermagie wieder.

[b][u]Grinding verboten?[/u][/b]
Anders als die meisten JRPGs belohnt Romancing Saga 2 Grinding nicht so wirklich. 
FÃ¼r die, die es nicht wissen: Grinding umfasst das BekÃ¤mpfen von Gegnern, ohne das ein Anlass abseits der Erfahrungspunke und des Loots besteht.
Je stÃ¤rker die Gruppe wird, desto stÃ¤rkere Monster tummeln sich in der Welt und manch eines ist in der Lage, leicht gepanzerte Gruppenmitglieder mit ein bis zwei SchlÃ¤gen Ã¼ber die Wupper zu schicken und sogar Bosse kÃ¶nnen auf diese Weise stÃ¤rker werden.
Das alles hat zwar Grenzen und mit Strategie und entsprechender AusrÃ¼stung kann man recht gut gegensteuern, aber all zu zeitig sollte man nicht damit in Betracht ziehen, einen Genozid an der lokalen Fauna anzustreben.

Wer doch mal in einer Sackgasse landet, kann mittels New Game+
einen neuen Anlauf starten. Das Spiel beginnt zwar wieder am Anfang, aber man kann die Meisterschaftslevel bis zu einem gewissen Punkt Ã¼bernehmen, was gerade zu Beginn ein riesen Vorteil ist.

[h1]Schwierigkeitsgrad[/h1]
Der Schwierigkeitsgrad von Romancing Saga 2 ist in einem hÃ¶heren Bereich angesiedelt, als in den meisten Genrekollegen und hÃ¤ngt davon ab, wie lernfÃ¤hig und experimentierfreudig der Spieler ist.
New Game+ und vor allem das freie Speichern sind hier aber ein Polster, um den Frust etwas zu mildern.

[h1]Soundtrack, Grafik, Steuerung[/h1]
Der Soundtrack ist hochwertig und gut umgesetzt, wie man es von Square ENIX kennt

Die Grafik ist in guter alter JRPG Manier gehalten, was Retrofreunde freuen dÃ¼rfte.

FÃ¼r die Steuerung eignen sich sowohl Maus und Tastatur als auch ein Controler.

[h1]Zusammenfassung[/h1]
[b]Pro:[/b]
[list]
[*] Offene Spielwelt
[*] MÃ¶glichkeit, Entscheidungen zu treffen, die was bewirken
[*] Fordernde KÃ¤mpfe
[*] Freies Speichern
[*] New Game+
 [/list]

[b]Kontra:[/b]
[list]
[*] Features und Mechaniken werden nicht wirklich erklÃ¤rt
[*] Keine MÃ¶glichkeit, im laufenden Spiel, ein Ã¤lteres Spiel zu laden
[*] LÃ¶sungen fÃ¼r Quests teils cryptisch
[*] "Glimmer" besteht aus viel versteckter Mathematik
      - Jeder Charakter hat einen "Glimmertyp"
        - Nicht jeder Glimmertyp lernt jeden Skill
           - Skills "glimmern" eher oder spÃ¤ter, je nach dem, gegen welche Gegner man kÃ¤mpft
[*] Manche Beschreibungen sind UnvollstÃ¤ndig

[/list]

[b]Neutral:[/b]
[list]
[*] Gegner "leveln mit"
[/list]

[b]Fazit:[/b]
Romancing Saga 2 ist keine leichte Kost. Viele Dinge erscheinen willkÃ¼rlich und vor allem das Glimmersystem in Kombination mit den mitlevelnden Gegnern kann einem Neuling im Spiel schon mal das Leben schwer machen. Fehlender ErklÃ¤rungen im Spiel zu den Mechaniken sind ebenfalls ein Faktor, der Spielern die sich lieber an die Hand nehmen lassen, als Dinge einfach auszuprobieren nicht selten den SpaÃŸ nimmt. 
Wirklich in eine Sackgasse kann man durch das Vererbungssystem und New Game+ zwar nicht geraten, aber das VerlustgefÃ¼hl ist da.
Alles in Allem habe ich das Spiel genossen und kann eine Kaufempfehlung an die Mutigen da drauÃŸen aussprechen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001195560', 'num_games_owned': 719, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 2655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2655, 'last_played': 1639178154}
review:
I've done most optional content and completed all the sidequests, but the final boss.. might be a hard skip.  It has almost 4x more HP'n the 2nd highest HP boss in his *boosted hard mode form, in a game where every boss battle is already tight 'cause of just how limited yer MP is, and it has a ridiculous moveset that absolutely requires a few very specific high level fusion spells.. that are missable 'cause of the whole "need to advance a generation in order to research new fusion spells", I'm in the final generation, and I can't advance time anymore

Heck, you can barely even grind at this point, 'cause the NPC who sells life potions stops selling 'em, and this game has a permadeath system where once one of yer character goes down, it starts losing life points and once that reaches zero, boom gotta recruit a new grunt and grind their spells up from scratch, like oldschool DnD.  Besides, grinding doesn't really do anything anyway since again, characters only get stronger as generations passes, and the only stat that you can level up is HP, and yer spells.. which holy shit you'd need to pretty much use 'em almost exclusively for the entire game in order to unlock the ones you actually need.. if you knew about 'em a few generations in advance so you'd actually have the time to research 'em

It's just one of those clunky old games where you get to the end on yer first playthrough, find out yer fucked, and are forced to do an entirely new playthrough, which.. conveniently there's a NG+ feature unlocked from the getgo and highlighted on the main menu, where you can just reset at any time and keep everything, like they knew

But I cba, 'cause the game.. isn't even too great in the first place.  The generational thing is neat at first, but the whole never really getting any stronger, starting over from mostly zero each time, and having to know everything in advance 'cause so many crucial things are so easily missable just.. sucks

But gee, Romancing SaGa isn't doing so great so far.  1 was already clunky and mostly tiresome, but it at least had some charm and was fun enough, mostly 'cause you could actually build up a stable party throughout the entire game and the things you found from exploring were neat, but 2 is just.. quite a step backwards.  A helluva lot less content, a really limiting design, no point to exploring at all, and it's just.. ironically very painfully linear, despite being advertised as being "much more open-world than the previous game".  Considering how many folks say 2 is the best one in the trilogy, I don't have much hope for 3

TL;DR : can't beat Romancing SaGa 2's final boss 'cause of bad game design, and cba to do a new playthrough 'cause the game just ain't too great, moving on to hopefully better Romancing SaGa 3 after a break

author: {'steamid': '76561198103651772', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1667002905}
review: Unfortunately I bought this game on a 3rd-party site so I couldn't refund it. It would have been only my second requested refund ever on Steam, and the other game is also a Square re-release/port. I don't even mind that it's 30 FPS, but the screen jitters all over the place inconsistently enough to be maddening! How do you mess something up emulators mastered years ago? One of the few Steam games that makes my eyes bleed and head spin. It actually seems like a really cool game, but the fundamental gameplay element of "Don't nauseate the customer." is missing.

review: Really not a fan of this one. Very light on story and very heavy on grinding. Doesn't actually explain mechanics ahead of time. author: {'steamid': '76561198113840439', 'num_games_owned': 1868, 'num_reviews': 320, 'playtime_forever': 1015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1015, 'last_played': 1620975962}
review:
It takes a special kind of patience to enjoy this game. I'd recommend at least briefly looking over a guide to save yourself a lot of aggravation. Nothing is explained in game, many systems have hidden values and sometimes you are given zero direction on what to do. But for an SNES game this is pretty impressive in the openness in quest structure and how you can tackle it overall. It was way ahead of it's time.

The most annoying thing for me is battles are not random and you can see enemies on the map. But they are fast and seem to target you no matter what. To make matters worse if you are not slow walking you automatically get ambushed which changes your formation to the default. There are a ton of enemies in rooms and most are impossible to avoid.

There are no characters in this just classes you can recruit. The game uses a generation system where your heir takes over for you if you die or if you progress the story at intervals. The system doesn't really add anything and is kind of stupid since people you recruited 150 years ago are all still standing in the same spot doing the same thing just future generations. It's extremely annoying where a generation shift does happen since you have to track down your party members you want again and equip them all again. You can late game spent a lot of money buying a building which has all the characters.

Worth a try but not for $25. I got it for $10 on sale and enjoyed it but gave up eventually.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052977989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1696564215}
review:
I really like this SaGa game ^^. I know it has "mixed" reviews, but I want to try and help anyone that is on the fence about this one after reading the negative reviews. 

When you load up the game the window is very tiny, there is no resolution change in the settings, but all you need to do is just drag the window larger and the game remembers that aspect ration every time. It's the same with Romancing SaGa 3 and SaGa Scarlet Grace, the game remembers whatever aspect ratio you last used the window <3. 

People also said bugs in the game, so far after 12 and a half hours into my run, the only bug I have encounter(which could also be my controller being old XD). Is that my "accept" button gets jammed in spamming accept in combat and *once* during ONE window of dialogue. In combat this is easy to fix when it happens, all you need to do is just press the B button to cancel the accept spamming, and from there you can go back to the beginning of the turn. 

This SaGa game is really fun, it's very story driven and I've always found it easy finding things to do. Except I recently did have a hard time finding the very last quest in the Prologue to complete XD. The councillor opposite the storeroom is very helpful in telling you what you have to do, and it's really fun finding new locations by speaking to everyone. 

I love how this game has so much choice in it <3. My first SaGa from was SaGa Frontier 2, so I never grew up with a JRPG with so much freedom. 

I think this is also an easier Romancing SaGa to start off with instead of Romancing SaGa 3. I just like this game, but I'm a super big fan of the SaGa series <3! 

I hope that my tips about how to fix the problems that I personally encountered in this version of the game is helpful to those on the fence about this game <3. The story is really good, the pixel art is really good, the character sprites are *adorable*, and as always, I love Kenji Ito's music <3!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993205533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 14884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6661, 'last_played': 1692462106}
review: Romancing SaGa 2 is not afraid to mercilessly rip apart and destroy your party, and I love it. The game is a constant challenge, but (mostly) never an unfair one. Pay close attention to why you died. Often a new formation, different set of armor, or abusing the right techniques will win you the fight. Even full party wipes can be beneficial, for this is a chance to gain a new emperor, build a new team, and learn new formations. Lots of room for experimentation and high replay value.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993727469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1600708778}
review:
THIS IS NOT A FINAL FANTASY CLONE

If you try to play it like most other JRPGs, you're gonna have a bad time. Characters revive/fully heal between battles, potions have to be equipped (1 per character per battle) and can revive someone who is down, the party leader is the only one who can order the party to flee and all characters have perma-death.

Grinding is difficult and there are no random battles. Once you beat the boss of a dungeon, it is empty. So if you have to start over with a new party (and you will have to), they will have to grind where the last party died. 

It has been a lot of fun so far but you have to come at it with a completely different mindset than FF/Chrono Trigger/Etc

author: {'steamid': '76561198169895105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1598150650}
review: The SaGa series is a great RPG series full of depth and exploration and Romancing SaGa 2 shows this incredibly well. The generational stuff is interesting and provides a lot of customization. I would say if you aren't really experienced in RPGs you shouldn't play this game, it's hard and if you don't know what you are doing you will die a lot. Overall a great port (It being in English is a big part of it) I wasn't a big fan of the visuals at first, but I can appreciate that they are way more colourful like Romancing SaGa 1 more, I'd say the font is the only terrible part.

review:
Jeu achetÃ© il y a Ã  peu prÃ¨s 2 ans, j'ai finalement dÃ©cidÃ© de me le faire cette semaine (Ã  coup de 10 heures par jour, Ã§a va vite). J'avoue avoir fais assez peu de jeux dans le genre J-RPG mais j'ai beaucoup vu et regardÃ© des jeux du genre.

Alors vaut-il le coup ? Eh bien oui ! Mais il peut ne pas plaire Ã  tout le monde et surtout il ne faut pas se dÃ©courager les premiÃ¨res heures.

Tout d'abord, il faut savoir que le jeu fonctionne de maniÃ¨re assez spÃ©ciale (je comptais vous faire part de cela mais je me rends compte qu'il me faudrait des pages entiÃ¨res et que je n'ai probablement qu'effleurer le fonctionnement). Si cela peut crÃ©er de l'incomprÃ©hension et de la difficultÃ© au joueur, on comprend vite avec les heures que cela a Ã©tÃ© plutÃ´t bien pensÃ© pour offrir une expÃ©rience originale et agrÃ©able au joueur. Ne pensez pas par contre pouvoir vous passer d'une page google en fond du jeu.

Les informations sont RARES, le jeu n'explique RIEN et vous allez passer un long moment Ã  essayer de comprendre et en plus ne comptez pas sur internet car le jeu est Ã  l'origine assez vieux et sortie au Japon uniquement. Donc pas Ã©normÃ©ment de forum, peu de rÃ©sultat google, encore moins de guide vidÃ©o et en FranÃ§ais vous trouverez rien ou presque. Mais ne vous y trompez pas, le jeu ne vous bloque jamais et vous avez Ã©normÃ©ment de choses Ã  faire donc si vous coincez quelque part, revenez-y plus tard.

Parlons de la carte, elle se dÃ©compose de la maniÃ¨re suivantes : la mappemonde, les zones puis les lieux (endroit ou vous contrÃ´lez votre perso tel qu'un donjon, une ville, une grotte). Vous n'avez accÃ¨s qu'Ã  trÃ¨s peu de zone dans lesquels vous pouvez vous tÃ©lÃ©portez au dÃ©but du jeu et le jeu vous pousse donc Ã  partir Ã  l'aventure dans des territoires inconnus et hostiles et Ã  rencontrer les peuples qui habitent ce monde. Ce qui m'a Ã©tonnÃ© d'ailleurs c'est la variÃ©tÃ© des villes et villages du jeu, s'accordant toujours bien dans l'environnement.

Les musiques sont bonnes sans rÃ©volutionner la musique non plus. Vous apprÃ©cierez les aller-retour Ã  la capitale avec une musique que vous n'oublierez JAMAIS.

Le bestiaire du jeu est.... comment dire... spÃ©cial ? Mais sachez que si vous voulez de la bestioles variÃ©es, vous allez Ãªtre servi !

Le jeu me laisse toujours cette impression d'avoir Ã©tÃ© dur mais en y repensant je n'ai galÃ©rÃ© vraiment que sur le dernier boss (PrÃ©parez vous bien !) et c'est pour moi ce qui l'a rendu agrÃ©able. Une difficultÃ© bien dosÃ© mais qui ne vous frustrera pas. Le jeu sait vous mettre la pression sans vous forcer Ã  devoir cheese ou use bug l'IA du jeu et quand on voit certains jeux d'aujourd'hui ou c'est soit l'un soit l'autre que l'on vous demande, Ã§a fait du bien.

Sachez qu'il est probable que dans quelques annÃ©es je refasse le jeu, diffÃ©remment pour avoir une autre expÃ©rience de celui-ci et de dÃ©couvrir ce qu'il peut encore me cacher.

Foncez si vous aimez le genre et que vous n'avez pas peur d'apprendre le fonctionnement du jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198849838717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1609005004}
review:
NÃ£o fechei o jogo ainda, mas, pelo pouco que joguei, posso observar que Ã© RPG bem incomum:
- NÃ£o dÃ¡ para se apegar a qualquer personagem, visto que, ainda que nos esforcemos para que ele permaneÃ§a vivo, hÃ¡ pontos no jogo onde se passam 100 anos e vocÃª Ã© obrigado a passar o trono a um herdeiro, sendo necessÃ¡rio formar uma nova party. AlÃ©m do mais, hÃ¡ o LP, uma marcador que indica quantas vidas seu personagem tem. Ao zerar esse LP, esse personagem morre para sempre no game e vocÃª Ã© obrigado e substituir por outro boneco do castelo. Se for o imperador que tiver essa LP zerada, vocÃª terÃ¡ que escolher um herdeiro. E nÃ£o hÃ¡ muitos itens em abudÃ¢ncia para aumentar essa LP. Logo, se vocÃª quer manter ao mÃ¡ximo um personagem vivo, evite ao mÃ¡ximo que ele nunca zere o HP durante batalhas.
- VocÃª como imperador tem uma quantidade limitada de skills para acumular. Caso vocÃª queira aprender uma tÃ©cnica nova e mais poderosa, terÃ¡ que se "esquecer" de outra jÃ¡ existente.
- Se vocÃª quer ter acesso a armas e magias melhores, Ã© muito recomendÃ¡vel que o impÃ©rio invista em pesquisas, e isso custa muito dinheiro. Por isso Ã© sempre importante estar resolvendo as quests que envolvem dinheiro....
- Ã‰ muito importante analisar qual tipo de formaÃ§Ã£o vocÃª usarÃ¡ antes das batalhas. Inicialmente, a formaÃ§Ã£o Imperial Cross parece ser inquestionavelmente melhor, mas, ao longo do jogo, veremos suas desvantagens...
-  Romancing Saga Ã© um tipo de jogo onde ficar tentando upar personagens nÃ£o parece ser muita vantagem. Nas dungeons nÃ£o hÃ¡ pontos para poder recuperar os SP e MP dos personagens, alÃ©m dos inimigos voltarem apÃ³s entrar ou sair de um ambiente se a dungeon ainda nÃ£o foi finalizada. EntÃ£o Ã© sempre bom dosar o uso de itens que aumentam o MP e SP, mesmo que vocÃª sempre tenha em abundÃ¢ncia alternativas para recuperar o HP.
- Apesar dos comandos simples, nÃ£o sei o que fizeram nessa adaptaÃ§Ã£o para a mobilidade dos bonecos ser tÃ£o travada. Ao tentar deslocar o boneco, parece que demora a responder. E, quando vocÃª corre, ele ainda continua andando em velocidade durante alguns milisegundos. Isso Ã© pÃ©ssimo durante as dungeons, pois vocÃª quer evitar inimigos, e nÃ£o consegue justamente pela movimentaÃ§Ã£o ser travada....
- Os menus sÃ£o bem simplÃ³rios, o que dificulta analisar como montar o personagem. Por exemplo, se vocÃª quer saber o que uma armar, uma armadura, ou o que um item faz, vocÃª terÃ¡ que navegar pelos menus de inventÃ¡rio ou ir no estoque do seu castelo para saber o que exatamente aquele item faz. Nos menus bÃ¡sicos, vocÃª nÃ£o tem qualquer informaÃ§Ã£o de quais atributos uma arma, armadura ou item ajudam a melhorar (ou piorar).

Resumindo, Romancing Saga 2 nÃ£o Ã© um jogo fÃ¡cil. Para aqueles mais hardcore que se importam com nÃ­vel de dificuldade, estratÃ©gias e pensar em como montar um personagem, Ã© um jogo que recomendo. Agora, se for para ter uma higiene mental, como se fosse assistir a um anime, com historinhas e romances, esqueÃ§a... Definitivamente Romancing Saga nÃ£o Ã© um jogo onde possamos nos apegar a historinhas e personagens preferidos....

author: {'steamid': '76561198218956109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2348, 'last_played': 1654574008}
review: Romancing SaGa 2 doesn't play like your standard Super Nintendo Square JRPG. However, it's still real easy to pick up and play as well as full of mechanical depth. The game promotes trying all kinds of weapon and class combinations until you find out what sticks and more importantly what you enjoy. What the game lacks in a focused narrative it allows you to fill in with a sense of adventure similar to the board game Gloomhaven. My favorite example is of Lord Dynamite the Monk King who fell in love with a mermaid and then freed the Mole People of the Savannah from termites. If you're looking for something different and love oldschool JRPG's then this is for you. Be warned that if you look online for help or advice with these types of games that there aren't too many available resources. But I'd argue that's for the best as the game is more fun blind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091694610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1563292453}
review:
Il solito porting svogliato made in Square Enix, pensato per il mobile e trapiantato di peso su PC. Il gioco gira a 30 fps laddove l'originale per SNES ne contava 60, i menu e l'interfaccia sono studiati per essere fruiti da smartphone e come sempre non Ã¨ stato fatto il benchÃ© minimo sforzo per adattare i testi alla lingua italiana, limitando la selezione al solo giapponese e all'inglese. A questo si aggiunge la complessitÃ  e la ragguardevole etÃ  del gioco, il tutto venduto ad un prezzo sin troppo alto per quello che il prodotto ha da offrire, soprattutto alla luce del pessimo lavoro di adattamento e modernizzazione.

Il medesimo trattamento Ã¨ stato riservato anche a Romancing Saga 3, che sconsiglio a sua volta e mi astengo dal comprare, se non in fortissimo sconto.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024953074', 'num_games_owned': 8948, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 9452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9338, 'last_played': 1571782128}
review:
I'm finding it difficult to review Romancing SaGa 2. I ended up loving it, but only after I had read up on some key information about the game mechanics that would have taken my dumb ass forever to figure out without help, potentially long enough for me to quit early. I'm going to go through a couple of the things that I found to be important knowledge, so this is going to be a pretty ranty review.

The music is excellent. In my 150+ hours of playing this game I never got sick of hearing it.

The story felt a bit difficult to stay too invested in. While the open nature of the game and the generation /inheritance system is unique for its time and are good gameplay elements, the sheer number and varying lifespans of each emperor/party member means there's not a lot to follow on a personal level (which may have been the intent?).

The encounters being handled by avoiding/engaging hostile creatures on the map is neat and I love the turn-based combat, but some of my biggest gripes is with how the game displays your attributes. The attributes list a DEF stat which is affected by armor, but it doesn't tell you that it's only one of [b]EIGHT[/b] different resistances each armor piece or accessory provides, and the game will never give you exact numbers for the other resistances, remaining vague by either being named something obvious or having a very short description. If the game was more descriptive about the stats (it should be, there's plenty of room) it would save a lot of headache from trial-and-erroring equipment pieces against various attack types, assuming you don't look them up online.

You might have also heard that the game has scaling difficulty. I had, so I was naturally very cautious about engaging in too many battles. Thankfully, as long as you stay on top of your equipment research and don't flee too much, battles should remain bearable. The scaling has a limit and it caps out at around [spoiler]700 to 800[/spoiler] fights. Even if you work yourself into a situation where the scaling has cornered you and you can't catch up by killing anything, the additional content this remaster provides (assuming you kept it enabled at the start) can be used to fight weaker enemies to hopefully catch up.

On that note, let's talk about the remaster part of this. The game runs at a chunky 30 FPS, there are 3 options (Walk/Dash default, Battle text speed, Mouse UI toggle) in-game, you seemingly can't enforce an aspect ratio so the pixels don't get squashed and the game starts getting this weird frame skip issue if it's been running for a couple hours so you start zipping around everywhere. It's stable though, I only had it crash once and it was when I was closing the game anyway so it didn't even matter. I did have a weird issue where your character stops moving if you hold diagonally on the D-pad, but with any other control (analog stick, keyboard) the movement was fine which was annoying. The "HD makeover" also feels a bit odd, the environments look nice, but really remind me of basic RPGMaker assets and it clashes with the sprites that were kept from the original.

Now, who should get this? If you're resourceful enough to get and play the original, great. Game's definitely worth playing. Already played the original? Maybe don't bother. The additional content isn't mindblowing by any means. New to JRPGs in general? Probably not a good choice, RS2 is known for being one of the harder ones out there. I think the people who benefit from getting this the most are people who wanted a fully translated version of the game and don't mind paying a bit extra to not play it on mobile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047905904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1709210837}
review:
absolute trash. if you enjoy games that dont bother trying to explain ANY of their mechanics, while also having every single mechanic so heavily buried in RNG and obscure invisible triggers that the literal only way to understand the game at all is to read a detailed but outdated guide that uses "translated" japanese names for everything OR to spend hundreds of hours pouring through the games code, this is a game for you.

 if however you enjoy some degree of clarity, a sense of direction, and actual fun, this is far from your game. dont you dare try grinding levels to trigger the completely unexplained "sparking" mechanic, lest you level the enemies in the game so high everything 1 shots every party member. better not make the wrong choice for armor/weapon production, lest you reach the end game and have literally useless gear. level ups happen at complete random, and never seem to actually DO anything. i jumped from level 1-5 in punching over the course of maybe 15 fights, and did the exact same amount of damage each time. most of the skills are redundant, being just another skill with no effect but higher attack, but they give NO indication of a skills power. even its cost isnt an indication, as all the strongest skills cost as much as the bottom tier skills to use.

 music is okay. nothing to write home over. graphics are pretty bad. some parts (sprites, most enemies) look like a blown up distorted poor quality SNES sprite, while the backgrounds and SOME enemies have totally redone and good looking sprites/tiles so as to not look like a bunch of blurry pixels. this coupled with the use of some modern post processing effects/shaders causes everything to look awkwardly bad and clashing.

 NG+ is worthless. you lose everything you obtained your last game save for gear and items, which get deposited in the bank. so no, you dont get to have fun going back through the game roflstomping the enemy with end game skills, and because of HOW said skills work, if you ever equip your end game, or even mid game gear, your charcters power will be so high that youll never get a single skill to spark till your up to the area where you would normally get said gear.


 thats not too much of an issue though. the game is absurdly easy. until you face a boss, then you just watch all your guys get 1 shotted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046703757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1562182269}
review:
This game is very much an old school rpg. 
main con: this series is infamous/famous for telling you absolutely nothing about any mechanics, and what little the game tells you (ex: stats on weapons) may be misleading. If you want to experience an old school hard rpg, play this without internet guides the first time around. I would also recommend this any basically any SaGa game if you are looking for a series that's very different.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086141137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 5061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4384, 'last_played': 1660586875}
review:
[b]tl;dr SaGa games were flawed, epic, open ended, obscure gems way ahead of their time that few westerners got to play back in the days and that you should absolutely try if you're into (J)RPGs.[/b]

My first encounter with them was in the mid nineties with Romancing SaGa 3. Coming from the likes of Chrono Trigger or Final Fantasy VI, I was hella confused by it. Most of the world was freely accessible from the start and I kept going from villages to towns and from ships to islands into dark caves and dungeons which inevitably led to what seemed like invincible mighty opponents.

Still, despite missing most of the complex mechanics behind the game and unable to even read the few hints the game throws at you, I fell in love. The world seemed so vast and mysterious. The very distinctive music and graphics were very appealing, the dark yet epic atmosphere ... It was actually the first thing I ever checked for on the internet, back in the early days of gamefaqs. I didn't beat it until years after, in it's unofficial english translation. I went on to play and love SaGa Frontier on the PS1 as well, but never got to play Romancing SaGa 2 until this Steam release.

SaGa games, or at the very least Romancing SaGa 1, 2, 3 and SaGa Frontier 1, share very distinctive, coherent design choices both in gameplay and art direction. From the mind of Final Fantasy co-creator Akitoshi Kawazu, and transcended by the grandiose artwork of Tomomi Kobayashi and the epic compositions of Kenji Ito, you could say they are a little bit to Final Fantasy what the Silmarillion is to The Lord of the Rings. In the sense that while they're less concentrated on their protagonists and the development of a set storyline, they give you a sense of archaic legendary tale where anything can happen. 

Romancing SaGa 2 has all the qualities I just described, and yet is different from the others in many ways. Where the others give you a choice of several characters to start with to experience a world set in time, RS2 makes you play as a successive legacy of emperors that span several centuries, all tied to the same storyline. Your achievements get carried over each generation, and your emperor inherit the powers of its predecessors. The story is linked by the fight against the Seven Heroes, once heroic humans who saved the world, turned into malevolent superior beings by the power that corrupted them.

So you're the emperor of a small northern kingdom, vowed to uniting the world under his banner and rid the world of the Seven Heroes after experiencing their evil deeds first hand. Several classes of warriors are recruitable from the start to accompany you, and you will unlock more as you explore the world. Your castle will grow from your achievements, and the levels of yourself and the classes of your comrades will carry out from generation to generation. Generation skips occur semi-randomly at the end of certain quests. 160 years will pass in a screen. Your emperor and your comrades will be long gone, and your new emperor will raise and inherit the powers of it's predecessors, ready to take on their task. Things your ancestors have done will sometimes have changed the world in some way, which will be yours to discover.

This and semi-permadeath gives a very interesting depth to the game. Something dark yet hopeful. Time passes, yet the determination of your legacy does not weaken.

On permadeath. SaGa games have a Life Point system. Each playable character in the game have a set amount of them. In RS2, running out of LPs means your character is gone for good. If it happens to your emperor, it's generation skip time. Unless it's your last ... There are ways to get some back, but they are also very limited.

As I said, the game is "open-ended". Open world, you could almost say. In the sense that you get access to most of it straight way, and can choose to explore it as you like. You will be given few directions here and there on where to go or what to do, but they can be pretty vague, and it's up to you to do your own thing. The world is very varied, from medieval strongholds to jungles, desert and mountains. The sense of traveling is strongly conveyed.

Characters don't get levels per-se. HP will raise the more enemies you defeat. MP the more magic you use. Weapon skills are "sparked". As you raise your level in one of the 8 weapon classes available by using them in battle, your characters will "spark" skills semi randomly while using said weapon in battle. The unlocked skills will be available to your future generations. Remember to leave room for sparking new ones. Not knowing you could only have a limited amount of them active on a character at a time was one of my original downfalls in RS3 ...

I won't go any further about game mechanics. This is the kind of game you will have to research a bit about if you get enough into it to feel so inclined.

If you do, you will find that the game rewards you with a highly satisfying mix of fast, brutal, epic, technical battles. Despite their age, few games give you a sense of power the way SaGa games do. Unlocking new powerful skills and magic and finding new weapons can be game changing and bosses that seemed unbeatable suddenly fall to your new mighty strikes. Everything is overplayed, from the stances of your characters to the epic battle soundtracks.

Smart tactics will pay off as well. Changing battle formations, unlocking and using spells in clever ways. Equipment can also play a huge role and it's a shame this remaster didn't fix the fact the game doesn't tell you enough about it.

Which leads me to the "flawed" aspect, which applies more or less to the entire SaGa series as well. While a lot of the appeal of the games does come from the freedom and lack of set directions, there are times where the game straight out hide things from you, or permanently closes scenaristic doors you didn't even know were opened. You are sometimes given choice of action without being aware of it, which can have dramatic repercussions on occasions. Some core mechanics are completely hidden from you, as are special equipment resistances in RS2. Some armors will for example have strong resistances to certain elements, but the game doesn't tell you. Something that could have easily been fixed in this remake but sadly wasn't.

Thankfully, while small, the SaGa community is full of very dedicated people who have relentlessly written guides and information gathered from what i can only imagine must be thousands of hours of testing. There are in depth guides available on gamefaqs, and while I do recommend going semi-blind, you should at the very least read up on core mechanics like skill sparking and magic development. The game lets you save anywhere, anytime, which helps a lot on that aspect. But nonetheless, it is still possible to run into dead-ends far into the game if you're not a little bit prepared. Something that the remake's New Game Plus feature fixes in a way.

On the remake, I would say that's the way I wish became standard for Square. They kept the sprites. They kept the soundtrack. Some boss sprites are now animated while retaining their pixel art style and it looks pretty cool. All the backgrounds have been remade, and while they can look pretty bland at times, they're not bad, and I understand why they did it given the original RS2 wasn't the most appealing in that aspect. I do wish they keep the original ones for the much better looking RS3. There are a number of added features, like New Game Plus, new dungeons and 2 classes, all great additions that blend well with everything else.

All in all, again, highly recommended to (J)RPGs enthusiasts. If you can get over the initial shock of the unconventional gameplay, you're in for a grand time. 

I really hope for the game to do well here on Steam, so Square keeps releasing it's sequels and prequel and, who knows, maybe new installments one day. It's been a while and the love certainly hasn't died in Japan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198194284531', 'num_games_owned': 873, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 2674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2484, 'last_played': 1553736403}
review:
Romancing Saga 2 was originally released in the SNES and i could only play a little due to the game never being translated until recently.

In this game you are the emperor of Avalon, a small country which you can expand by helping other countries and/or conquering lands that we're infested by monsters, and your Capital grows accordingly to your expansions and money you possess, getting access to more characters, features and classes. You have many areas and quests you can access in any order you want, since this game gives you almost total freedom in exploration.

The Main antagonists in this game are The Seven Heroes: Having Saved the world 700 years ago, they suddenly reappeared again but this time destroying and terrorizing everyone.

Basically Romancing Saga 2 uses a system similar to Final Fantasy 2 where your characters only increase their strength based on what you do in battle. You take damage? Your maximum HP might increase. You use a Spear? You proeficiency in Spears increase. You use Fire Magic? Your Fire Magic damage increases. In addition your characters can use many formations while fighting, giving them certain advantages in battle. This game also has the inheritance system, where when your current Emperor/Empress their sucessor replaces them and receive the powers the previous Emperors possessed.

And one last thing that defines the SaGa franchise: The Freaking [spoiler]fucking[/spoiler] Hellish Difficult!
Yep, this game is WAY harder than the Final Fantasy series featuring a system where your enemies grow according to how many battles you've won, which means YOU CAN'T GRIND EXCESSIVELY! While this doesn't affect the bosses, it affects normal enemies making them in some extreme cases harder than the bosses itself. Train with Moderation.

Final Score: 8.8/10
Would definitely be wiped out in one hit again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297189004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1548461783}
review:
There's a reason one online periodical has called SaGa the most self-indulgent JRPG series of all time. And might I add, the most masochistic.

SaGa is a polarizing series. While Unlimited SaGa for PS2 was widely considered one of the worst games on the console by American reviewers, a veritable train-wreck that gets just about everything wrong, there are still people on the internet who call it a gem, the reviewers just couldn't appreciate it for its rarified greatness (yeaaaaahhh, I'm not investing in THAT bridge). Japanese tastes in gaming are just odd in general and should not taken as in any way "superier" to western.

Don't let the stuck up elitists fool you. This, and the other SaGa games, are awful. They fail and catastrophically as game design. It's not even the weak, disjointed and skeletal story structure accompanied by too much open-endedness and cardboard dialogue, that's the worst of it. Many gamers (I think myself included) can just about handle that if the gameplay is right. But it ISN'T. It ISN'T. You see, the makers of this remaster were so conservative with the original gameplay and code, only giving this a fresh coat of aesthetic paint, that all the flaws of a nut-cult game that (happily) never made it overseas before, are retained. For one thing, the departure from random battles (DQ, early FF) in lieu of on-screen mobs is handled so poorly, you could not even compare it with the proper implementation in Chrono Trigger. These enemies scurry around incredibly fast and in your direction before you even open doors, so you can hardly ever avoid them, especially in cramped dungeons. So you constantly get into simplistic, grindy battles with weird static sprites that raise your battle count. And with that rising battle count, all the encounters and bosses in the entire game world continue to go up in difficulty (a concept that is implemented decently in Final Fantasy VIII and Vagrant Story, but abysmally here). And your fleeing from a battle results in nothing more than a slight pause where that mob (and others on screen) just continue to chase you around at the same speed as your sprint. So this makes for a comical scenario where you repeatedly run into it with the SAME MOB all over again, continuing to raise battle count. And if you try to sprint, you easily lose you formation making all battles even tougher. As a rule your beefing-up from battles is dwarfed by the usefulness of finding more powerful equipment, so you can accidently grind yourself into a corner in this game by fighting too many battles ... that the game hardly lets you avoid! Oh, and there is nothing like a recall scroll/escapipe to let you get out of these awful dungeons, where you're madly dashing to get away from mobs and many treasure chests are also mobs (unless there is a later-game spell and item that lets you recall?, but it's a travesty that it isn't there for newbies). There is at least a New Game+ option that allows some parts of your progress to carry over so you can achieve a more realistic chance of success, but it's not fun to spend hours progressing just to go all the way back because the game is unbalanced as all get out. Chrono Trigger did New Game+ right, whereas this remaster only includes it as a band-aid on bad game design.

SaGa is the odd black sheep of the whole Squenix roost to be frank.

Don't let anyone tell you this is a flawed port of a good game. Where do they get that idea? The underlying game was always terrible. I couldn't even equip a mace weapon on my light infantry member who was using a sword previously, because its attack power was so nerfed from the sword that it made no sense to make such a switch (so much for freeform character growth, not with that travesty battle-count mechanic that constantly corners your supposedly free choice).

The successful way to break away from the mold is carefully. Beethoven made great music by deviating slightly and efficiently from the precedent of Mozart and Haydn. He knew nothing of an aberration like atonal or twelve-tone serialism, or mucking around with a prepared piano and household objects and to call that "music". This is like that in terms of gaming. DO NOT WANT

author: {'steamid': '76561197970558747', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1574899961}
review:
The game is probably OK, but this is a terrible port.
Nothing is labelled on the screen, you just have to assume you know where your TP and MP are.
The movement is weird, feels a bit clunky when you try to run around.
Sometimes the A button just goes rapid fire for no apparent reason.

It's playable, but the game is frustrating enough without the bad GUI and terrible menu layout. If they are going to try and modernize the layout, at least make it better than the original. Not worse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030778236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1546037836}
review:
If you have never played JRPGs before, this is probably not where you want to start. The dialogues are a little barebone and the mechanics are foreign at first, but once you get into it, it's a really great game. You have to be smart and it's challenging, perhaps not quite fair at times, but not much of an issue since you can save anywhere, anytime. 

As for the quality of the port: I have 0 complaint. Controller works like charm, no input lag,.. I am not sure what kind of options you'd want to have that are missing. 

In all candor, it boils down to the price tag, and whether you want to play it bad enough you are willing to fork over $20+ on a 1993 game. It was worth it for me, may not be for you. So take full advantage of those first 2 hours to make your mind :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198035359461', 'num_games_owned': 52, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2599, 'last_played': 1543110574}
review:
An outstanding remaster of an amazing game that never made it West before now.  Make no mistake, this game is difficult and sometimes frustrating.  It took me about 20 hours to finally get the hang of things, and I have played SaGa Frontier, Romancing SaGa 3, and Romancing SaGa (PS2)  with well over 500 hours combined in playthroughs.  When I finally began cruising along through this title, this game put me in my place with the final boss.  It is not for the weak.

This game comes from a time long before tutorials and hand holding and admittedly is not for everyone.  But if you are a hard core JRPG fan and are looking for a serious challenge  with some of the best battle systems and music around, give Romancing SaGa 2 a shot. 

I highly anticipate the arrival of the remaster of 3 and any other new games in this series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035230266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 776, 'last_played': 1562521747}
review:
The 3 Romancing SaGa were the best of the SaGa series in my book.

In a nut shell, you play as a vassal to acquire skills and knowledge to prepare for your confrontation against the so called 7 heroes and the ultimate evil.  The mechanics is a little different here in that your "main character" is meant to pass on his/her essence to the next in line until you unlock the final emperor/empress.  

For those that get upset from "losing" your character... another way to look at it, you are playing an immortal character that changes the skin every so often.  It was just another meat bag until you get to your final form :P

RS2 is where they gone and try something new and different, and experiment with the generation formula that you've seen in some of the other later games, such as the Record of Agarest War series, or even something like Kynseed.  Keep in mind that RS2 was made back in 1993 for the Japanese Super Ninendo, with all sorts of hardware limitation.  Despite all that, they still manage to make this massive and grindy sand box RPG.  But what really impressed me is that they took all the learnings from this game and created Romancing SaGa 3, my all time favorite SaGa game.  

In terms of the port, they did a decently good job.  Keyboard game play is actually functional, but I ended up playing with a controller anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010139041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1652308659}
review:
I really wanted to like this game.  It has interesting classes/abilities, a unique progression system (for characters, not the XP base).

Unfortunately, this is just too much for me.

* You have no idea the difficulty of what you're walking into, difficulty wise.
* The game seems to be based on the 'more battles = more difficulty', but this includes if you flee from battle
* The enemies exist as characters on the map, and will disappear when you slay them.  If you flee, they'll remain.  So it's possible to get yourself trapped endlessly. 
* It's easy to accidentally miss something (alternate paths, for example) based on timing.
* The bosses can be on an exceedingly difficult level of difficulty from the enemy mobs around them.  


If you like that sort of thing, more power to you, but it didn't work out for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106165594', 'num_games_owned': 432, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1669289256}
review: Final Fantasy Legend, that's where I began with the SaGa series. They updated the Steam version to this game to get rid of that awful mobile on-screen button garbage. So, I don't see any real problems in regards to the UI. The gameplay is quite fun and I can see some similarities with that of FFL. One thing I would have liked is the option to rename all of our characters like in FFL rather than being stuck with fixed names, I like playing as my own characters. However, you can easily rename the fixed character names via a hex editor by editing the resources.assets file, only one edit is needed. Anyways, I'm giving this the thumbs up because it's turning out to be a fun game and it really does bring back the FFL days to me.

A franquia usa um sistema de construÃ§Ã£o de personagem onde os personagens melhoram dependendo do que eles fazem em batalha, dependendo do que usam, aÃ§Ãµes que tomam, com isso, os Stats dos personagens aumentam dependendo do que eles fazem! Isso significa que seu personagem nÃ£o atacar em batalha, e sÃ³ ficar defendendo, ele nÃ£o melhorarÃ¡ em ataque, jÃ¡ que ele nÃ£o estÃ¡ atacando, e nÃ£o hÃ¡ nÃ­veis para ele ganhar no final da batalha.

Armas tambÃ©m tem seus nÃ­veis, mas nÃ£o armas individuais, mas sim os tipos de arma, como por exemplo, Espada (em geral) e Machado (em geral). Quanto mais vocÃª usa esse tipo de arma em batalhas, ela poderÃ¡ subir de nÃ­vel, e com isso, farÃ¡ mais dano. 

TambÃ©m hÃ¡, outro em batalha, onde, vocÃª, quando vocÃª ataca os inimigos, tens uma chance de aprender habilidades de ataque, que custam pontos, mas podem dar danos altos. EntÃ£o, vocÃª tem os ataques normais, vÃ¡rios e vÃ¡rios ataques de habilidade para cada arma e as magias-nÃ£o-tÃ£o-Ãºteis.

Ã‰ um jogo nÃ£o-linear, apÃ³s um certo ponto no comeÃ§o, vocÃª poderÃ¡ visitar as cidades livremente, e, falando com os NPCs, eles citarÃ£o outras cidades, e localizaÃ§Ãµes especiais, que vocÃª poderÃ¡ visitar para desbloquear mais ainda...HÃ¡ muitas cidades, muitas dungeons, vÃ¡rias localizaÃ§Ãµes especiais! VocÃª nÃ£o atravessa o Overworld do jogo, mas sim, simplesmente escolhe a localizaÃ§Ã£o desbloqueada, poupando tempo e indo direto ao ponto: Onde vocÃª quer ir agora. 

O mapa Ã© dividido em regiÃµes, cada uma com um problema a ser resolvido, como, por exemplo, MONSTROS. ApÃ³s resolver o problema ou os problemas, a regiÃ£o Ã© desbloqueada, e vocÃª poderÃ¡ acessÃ¡-la com um simples clique no mapa do mundo. 

No mapa do mundo hÃ¡ todas as regiÃµes do jogo, e dentro dessas regiÃµes hÃ¡ todas as localizaÃ§Ãµes dessa regiÃ£o, mas isso se desbloquear todas!

Eles voltaram, sim, estÃ£o de volta. Um impÃ©rio ao norte do mundo descobre essa volta e assim partem em uma jornada para derrotar os Sete HerÃ³is e retornar paz no mundo. 

Como o jogo Ã© nÃ£o-linear, vocÃª irÃ¡ encontrÃ¡-los livremente enquanto atravessa o mundo, com somente dicas de NPCs para onde ir e as localizaÃ§Ãµes. 

ApÃ³s vocÃª resolver um problema no mundo e liberar uma regiÃ£o, o jogo "acabarÃ¡" e vocÃª irÃ¡ para um ano aleatÃ³rio (ex: 50 anos depois) e poderÃ¡ escolher o novo protagonista, que Ã© um herdeiro desse impÃ©rio. VocÃª pode ir indo assim e avanÃ§ar vÃ¡rios anos com vÃ¡rias geraÃ§Ãµes diferentes dos guerreiros do impÃ©rio, formando uma...histÃ³ria, bem, bem Ã©pica, heh.

VocÃª tambÃ©m pode formar uma Party inteira de atÃ© 5 personagens livremente espalhados no castelo, o Ãºnico que terÃ¡ que se manter nela Ã© o protagonista.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190669265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4835, 'last_played': 1598186892}
review:
I can't support this series hard enough, and I'd be lying if I didn't have hopes that they'll start releasing more of the SaGa games.
I started with SaGa Frontier, a PS1 game, that was fairly buggy near end game, but it was glorious storywise, the graphics were beautiful(for it's time), and the cast vast and engaging.

I really hope Squarenix gets around to rereleasing some of the games they did in the Earlier PS1 era, not just the Final Fantasy entries, but Chrono Cross, or SaGa Frontier as I mentioned earlier.

For first time players to the SaGa system, it might be a bit jarring at first, honestly I'd suggest not doing anything real plot heavy in your first run through and abuse the New Game +, so you can carry over a good deal of your weapon proficiencies, which will increase damage as well as to-hit-chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000743905', 'num_games_owned': 553, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1519281083}
review:
This is a port of the mobile port of the original SNES game. It has few adjustable settings and while it supports keyboard controls, they are not recommended. I do recommend reading the instruction manual that comes with the game.

All that said, I am glad that this classic Square Enix JRPG has finally gotten an English translation and a worldwide release. As someone who is far too aquainted with the classic turn-based systems of the Final Fanasy series, it is a pleasure to experience a similar game with so many unique mechanics, including adjustable party formations, perma-death, and kingdom management.

A wonderful classic for lovers of old-school JRPGs.
